Based on the search results, I found several Polish adaptations of Robinson Crusoe involving theater, film, and the character of Piętaszek (which is the Polish name for Friday). Here's what I discovered:

## Polish Theater Adaptations

ROMA Musical Theatre has a musical production called "Robinson Crusoe" for young audiences, playing on the NOVA STAGE, with its premiere on February 16, 2019. The production is based on Daniel Defoe's classic novel.

At Teatr Lalka, there's an adaptation by Ondrej Spisák with Wojciech Pałęcki as Robinson and Aneta Pałęcka as Piętaszek. This production at Teatr Lalka is formatted as participatory theater where the audience embarks on Robinson's sea voyage together. The production was created by two young Slovak artists, Ondrej Spišák and František Lipták.

## Character of Piętaszek

In Polish translations, Friday is known as Piętaszek. The rescued native is called Piętaszek (Friday, after the day of the week when he was met). There's discussion about why in every film Piętaszek is portrayed as a black boy, with some noting that in the book he was described as a young man with copper skin and long, black hair, more resembling someone of "Indian" appearance.

## Film Adaptations

The search results show various film adaptations, including an American adventure film from 1997 based on Daniel Defoe's novel and a Mexican adventure film from 1954 directed by Luis Buñuel, which was an adaptation of the classic novel by Daniel Defoe.

## Polish Literary History

The first Polish translation of the novel was commissioned by King Stanisław August Poniatowski and completed by Bishop Jan Chrzciciel Albertrandi, published in 1769 under the title "Przypadki Robinsona Kruzoe".

The search results indicate a rich tradition of Polish adaptations of Robinson Crusoe across multiple media, with particular attention to theatrical productions and the character of Piętaszek being a recognizable figure in Polish culture.
